abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, and negligible
            institutional development impacts, in addition to
            unsatisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower.
            Among the many lessons learned it is suggested a
            multi-sector area-based program requires a functional
            decentralized policy framework, and a supportive
            management/administrative structure. In addition, where
            institutional capacity is limited, project design and
            implementation arrangements should be kept simple. The
            project proved to be difficult to implement because the
            design included several sectors, and the project was
            implemented through several Government ministries and
            agencies. Innovative programs need to be assessed and
            institutionalized before scaling-up. A more rigorous
            assessment and institutionalization of the innovative
            area-based program would have provided a sounder basis for
            scaling up the program in the form of the Child Development
            Project. Most importantly, investing time and resources on
            community preparedness contributes to the sustainability and
            impact of community-based initiatives. The project
            illustrated that initiatives that respond to
            community-defined priorities (like the water schemes and
            community schools in this case) have a better chance of
            being sustained, whereas initiatives that are largely
            supply-driven and through vertical programs (in this case
            the Integrated Management of Childhood Illnesses (IMCI) and
            Community Based Nutrition (CBN) require activities to create
            the demand in order to increase service utilization.

5084728.trustfund:
TF037054-MENA REGION - REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH,TF025384-PHRD-CHILD DEVELOPMENT PROJECT (RECIPIENT-EXECUTED),TF025331-PHRD-CHILD DEVELOPMENT PROJECT (BANK-EXECUTED),TF036589-YEMEN - STUDY OF THE STATUS OF
            YOUNG CHILDREN

abstracts.cdata!:
The Child Development Project, aims at
            implementing the coordinated efforts of the pilot area-based
            program in Yemen, and improve the health, and nutritional
            status of children under five, and the educational status of
            girls in primary schools, specifically, in those districts
            currently under-served in health, and educational aspects.
            The components are the following: 1) Community readiness
            program, to provide training in assessing needs, planning,
            and social mobilization, to improve the community
            involvement in project participation. 2) Health, to
            strengthen the districts' health care system, in
            addressing relevant diseases, such as respiratory, and
            childhood diarrheal diseases, in addition to safe-motherhood
            and immunization. Construction works related to water
            supply, and sanitation, will be included. 3) Nutrition, to
            provide counseling, and nutrition education for improving
            children's nutritional status, and further address
            growth monitoring, and micro-nutrient supplements. 4)
            Education, to expand the girls' access to quality
            primary education, through innovative community-based
            schools. Women teacher training, and educational materials
            will be provided. 5) Early Child Development (ECD) pilot, to
            identify models for future expansion, towards improving
            access to education, among children in difficult
            circumstances, supported by studies on child rearing, and
            ECD interventions.
